metadata.sermon_start_end: HERE IS a political cartoon from the Palm Beach Post, reprinted in The New York Times last week. It shows a very high mountain, so high that it is partially enveloped in clouds. The summit of the mountain is designated “The Moral High Ground.” [...] O worship the King, all glorious above! O gratefully sing his power and his love.… His mercies, how tender, how true to the end; Our Maker, Defender, Redeemer, and Friend.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to identify what is unique to Deuteronomy 4:6-8. Instead of extracting the specific 'proclamatory word' of this pericope, the preacher uses it as a springboard for a general discussion on the relationship between the Testaments and contemporary political anecdotes.
quotes: Our texts this morning challenge us to examine Jewish faith and our own faith in a new light.
The relationship of the Old Testament to the New is a major issue for both Jews and Christians.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Isolate the specific claim of verse 7 regarding the 'nearness' of God in the context of the Sinai covenant, rather than treating it as a general 'living God' theme found throughout Scripture.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic awareness of the Torah's importance, but the exegesis is secondary to the use of modern commentaries and political news. The preacher relies on 'what the commentaries say' rather than demonstrating a direct engagement with the Hebrew text or the specific historical-theological context of the Deuteronomic reform.
quotes: I certainly didn’t [think it was special], until I read the commentaries and learned that biblical interpreters all say that it is 'radical'...
Deuteronomy is a very special book because of its references to God’s intimate relationship to the human heart.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond quoting modern scholars and demonstrate how the specific 'statutes and ordinances' of Deuteronomy 4 functioned as 'wisdom' for Israel in its ancient Near Eastern context.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete in its use of the Joe Lieberman example, which addresses the zeitgeist of the year 2000. However, it borders on being a speech about 'religion in the public square' rather than a direct application of the text's specific demand.
quotes: I’m talking about Lieberman because his selection... is a big-time news item.
The reaction of many assimilated Jews to Lieberman’s Orthodoxy shows us that the real issues are... between secular people and the community of faith.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the 'nearness of God' in the text to a specific contemporary spiritual or ethical crisis, rather than just a political news item.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured as a series of blocks: a political anecdote, a liturgical history lesson, a commentary on Mark, and finally a return to the text. The hearer is not 'drawn into the text' in a single movement; the text is used to validate external observations.
quotes: In any case, the combination of Deuteronomy with today’s Gospel presents a number of problems and challenges.
Now, however, we come back to Senator Lieberman...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Start with the text's own internal logic and allow the contemporary application to emerge from the exposition, rather than alternating between news and exegesis.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The preacher effectively addresses 'misery' through the 'infection of nature' and 'redemption' through the 'intervening presence of the living God.' It avoids being overly objective by addressing the 'messed up' heart of the hearer.
quotes: The basic problem is that our 'hearts' are messed up along with all the rest of us.
It can be changed only by the intervening presence of the living God.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure the 'gratitude' (the third part) is more than a general call to 'praise,' but a specific response to the 'statutes' mentioned in the text.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon avoids the 'two ways' almost entirely. While it mentions the 'infection of nature,' it lacks the urgency of the choice between life and death that characterizes Deuteronomy. The ending is safe and lacks the 'seriousness of being lost.'
quotes: You are God’s people whom he loves. You have been elected by him to reflect his glory in the world.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Incorporate the Deuteronomic warning that the 'wisdom' of the law is a matter of life and death, not just a 'religious identity.'

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the one who sweeps away categories of righteousness, but He feels more like a theological 'telos' imposed upon the text rather than the fulfillment of this specific passage. The doctrine of the two natures is not utilized to ground the nearness of God.
quotes: without the grace of God by Christ [going before] us.
the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Show how the 'nearness' of God in Deuteronomy 4 is specifically realized or transformed in the Incarnation of Christ.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18-19 minutes, the sermon falls just short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. While it covers broad ground, it lacks the 'breadth' of deep textual exploration, spending much time on external anecdotes.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Reduce the space given to political commentary and increase the depth of the textual exposition to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s ideal primarily because it functions as a topical speech about 'the living God' and 'religion in politics' rather than a specific exposition of Deuteronomy 4:6-8. It lacks the 'two ways' urgency and fails to identify what is unique to this specific pericope. However, it successfully avoids moralism by emphasizing the 'infection of nature' and the necessity of grace.
strengths: Adequate diagnosis of human misery through the 'infection of nature' concept.
Clear rejection of self-righteousness and 'spirituality' as human achievements.
Effective use of contemporary zeitgeist (the Lieberman case) to illustrate the 'otherness' of the living God.
weaknesses: Lack of specificity: the sermon could be preached on almost any text about God's presence.
Absence of the 'two ways': the seriousness of being lost is missing in favor of a comforting conclusion.
Structural fragmentation: exposition and application are treated as separate blocks rather than a single movement.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a 'speech about the gospel' rather than a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense. It fails the formal requirement of being an exposition of a specific passage that finds what can be found 'nowhere else.'
